definitions: travel from one place to another over a considerable distance
undergo a process of personal growth or spiritual development through experiences
examples: They journeyed across the desert for three days
The family journeys to Europe every summer vacation
She journeyed through grief to find peace again
The protagonist journeys from innocence to wisdom throughout

definitions: fight on horseback with lances as medieval knights did in tournaments
engage in a competitive debate or verbal sparring match with someone
examples: Knights would joust in tournaments to display their skill
The actors joust on horseback in the medieval festival
Politicians often joust over policy during televised debates
The lawyers jousted brilliantly in the courtroom yesterday

definitions: experience or express great happiness and delight about something
examples: She joyed in watching her children play together
They joyed at the news of their friend's recovery

definitions: take a vehicle without permission and drive it fast and dangerously for excitement
examples: Teenagers joyrided through the neighborhood in a stolen car
They were arrested for joyriding in their neighbor's vehicle

definitions: form an opinion or conclusion about someone or something after careful consideration
decide a case in a court of law as a legal authority
evaluate competitors or performances in a contest to determine winners
examples: Don't judge people by their appearance or first impressions
She judged him to be honest and trustworthy
The magistrate will judge the case next Monday morning
She judges cases in the family court division
They asked her to judge the talent show finals
He judges gymnastics competitions at the international level

definitions: keep several objects in the air by repeatedly throwing and catching them
manage or deal with several different tasks or situations at the same time
examples: The clown juggled five colorful balls at the circus
She learned to juggle oranges during her vacation
Working mothers often juggle career and family responsibilities daily
He juggles three part-time jobs to pay his bills

definitions: mix things up in a confused or untidy way without any order
examples: The children jumbled all the puzzle pieces together carelessly
Don't jumble the files or we'll lose important documents

definitions: push oneself off a surface into the air using leg muscles
increase suddenly and significantly in amount or value
make a sudden involuntary movement because of surprise or fear
move directly from one point to another omitting intermediate steps
examples: The athlete jumped over the high bar effortlessly
Children love to jump on trampolines at the park
Gas prices jumped twenty percent overnight during the crisis
The company's stock jumped after the earnings announcement
She jumped when the door slammed shut unexpectedly loud
He jumps every time the phone rings at night
Let's jump to the conclusion of this lengthy report
The movie jumps between different time periods confusingly

definitions: start a vehicle with a dead battery using cables connected to another battery
provide an initial stimulus to get something moving or progressing quickly
examples: Can you help jumpstart my car with your jumper cables?
The mechanic jumpstarted the truck using a portable battery
The government hopes to jumpstart the economy with stimulus
This workshop will jumpstart your creative writing career effectively

definitions: throw away or abandon something as useless or of poor quality
examples: They decided to junk the old computer and buy new
The company junked the failed product line last year

definitions: show or prove something to be right or reasonable through evidence or argument
adjust spacing in text so that lines align evenly at both margins
examples: How can you justify spending so much on entertainment?
The results justify our decision to invest more resources
Please justify the text in this document before printing
The word processor automatically justifies paragraphs for better appearance

definitions: travel in or paddle a small narrow boat propelled with a double-bladed paddle
examples: They kayaked down the river through beautiful canyon scenery
She kayaks every weekend at the nearby lake resort

definitions: fall over suddenly and collapse especially from illness or exhaustion
examples: He keeled over from heat exhaustion during the marathon
The old man suddenly keeled over at the bus stop

definitions: continue to have or retain possession of something without giving it away
continue doing an action or maintain a state without stopping
maintain something in a particular condition or position over time
store or put something regularly in a particular place
fulfill or honor a promise or commitment that was made
examples: She keeps all her childhood photographs in a box
Can I keep this book a little longer please?
Keep walking until you reach the traffic lights ahead
The rain kept falling throughout the entire night steadily
Please keep the door closed to maintain the temperature
They keep their garden beautiful with daily care routines
Where do you keep the spare keys for emergencies?
We keep the milk in the refrigerator door shelf
He always keeps his promises to his children faithfully
She kept her word about helping with the project

definitions: put a dog in a kennel for temporary boarding or housing
examples: They kenneled their dog while traveling abroad for vacation
We need to kennel the puppies before the storm

definitions: enter data or text using a keyboard or keypad device
establish or arrange music in a particular musical key or pitch
scratch or damage a surface deliberately using a metal key
examples: Please key in your password to access the system
She keyed the data into the spreadsheet all morning
The composer keyed the piece in B flat major
Can you key this song higher for the soprano?
Vandals keyed several cars in the parking lot overnight
Someone keyed my car door while I was shopping

definitions: deliver the main speech at a conference or event setting the central theme
examples: She will keynote the technology conference next month downtown
The professor keynoted three major symposiums this academic year

definitions: strike or propel something forcefully with the foot or feet
succeed in giving up a harmful habit or addiction permanently
react with strong force or recoil against something
examples: The player kicked the ball into the goal perfectly
Don't kick the door open when your hands are full
He finally kicked his smoking habit after twenty years
She's trying to kick her caffeine addiction this month
The rifle kicks hard when you fire it rapidly
The horse kicked against the stable door all night

definitions: joke with someone or tease them in a playful friendly manner
deceive or fool someone but not with serious harmful intent
examples: Stop kidding around and help me with this project
I was just kidding when I said that yesterday
Don't kid yourself about the difficulty of this task
Are you kidding me with that ridiculous price tag?

definitions: take someone away illegally by force typically to obtain ransom or concession
examples: The criminals kidnapped the businessman for a million-dollar ransom
They attempted to kidnap the diplomat's daughter last night

definitions: cause the death of a living being through violence or other means
put an end to or destroy something completely and finally
overwhelm someone with strong emotion or cause extreme reaction
examples: The disease kills thousands of people every year worldwide
Hunters kill deer during the regulated hunting season only
This new policy will kill small businesses in our community
They killed the project due to lack of funding
That comedian really kills me with his hilarious jokes
These new shoes are killing my feet terribly today

definitions: start a fire or cause something to catch fire and burn
arouse or inspire an emotion or feeling in someone
examples: They kindled a campfire using dry twigs and matches
She kindled the fireplace to warm the cold room
The speech kindled hope in the hearts of listeners
His words kindled her interest in ancient history immediately

definitions: form or cause to form a sharp twist or bend in something flexible
examples: The garden hose kinked and stopped the water flow
Don't kink the cable or it might break internally

definitions: provide someone or something with appropriate equipment or clothing for an activity
examples: They kitted out the expedition with survival gear completely
The school kits new students with necessary learning materials

definitions: fly a kite or cause something to fly high in the air with wind
fraudulently write or use a check without sufficient funds to cover it
examples: Children love to kite at the beach on windy days
We kited paper airplanes from the office building roof
He was arrested for kiting checks at multiple banks
The company kited funds between accounts to hide losses

definitions: lower oneself so that one or both knees rest on the ground
examples: She kneeled beside the injured child to help him
The knight kneeled before the king to receive honor

definitions: stab or cut someone or something with a knife blade weapon
examples: The attacker knifed his victim during the robbery attempt
She accidentally knifed her finger while cutting vegetables quickly

definitions: bestow the title of knight upon someone in a formal ceremony
examples: The Queen knighted him for his services to medicine
They knighted several citizens for their charitable work annually

definitions: make fabric or garments by interlocking loops of yarn with needles
join or cause to join together closely and firmly
examples: She knits sweaters for all her grandchildren every winter
I learned to knit from my grandmother years ago
The broken bones will knit together in six weeks
This experience knitted the team into a cohesive unit

definitions: strike a surface noisily to attract attention or gain entry
criticize someone or something in a harsh or unfair way
collide with something accidentally causing impact or displacement
examples: Please knock before entering my office for privacy reasons
Someone knocked loudly on the door at midnight yesterday
Critics constantly knock his performances without valid reasons
Don't knock it until you've actually tried it yourself
She knocked her elbow against the table corner painfully
The wind knocked the flower pots off the balcony

definitions: fasten or secure something with a knot by tying rope or string
become twisted or tangled together in a complex mass
examples: She knotted the rope securely around the wooden post
Can you knot this tie properly for the interview?
Her hair knotted badly after swimming in salt water
The fishing lines knotted together in the tackle box

definitions: be aware of something through observation study or being informed
have developed a relationship with someone through meeting or experience
be able to distinguish or recognize someone or something from experience
examples: I know the answer to your difficult question already
She knows three languages fluently including Mandarin Chinese
I've known Sarah since we were in elementary school
Do you know anyone who works at that company?
I would know that voice anywhere in the world
She knows quality wine when she tastes it immediately

definitions: press or rub something with the knuckles of the hand
apply oneself seriously to a task with determination and effort
examples: She knuckled her tired eyes after reading all night
He knuckled the dough firmly to work it properly
You need to knuckle down and study for exams
They knuckled under to the pressure from upper management

definitions: attach a label to something for identification or information purposes
assign someone or something to a category often in a restricting way
examples: Please label all the boxes before shipping them tomorrow
She carefully labeled each jar with its contents date
Society tends to label people based on first impressions
They labeled him a troublemaker unfairly without knowing facts

definitions: work hard physically or mentally especially for long periods of time
move or proceed with difficulty and great effort
examples: Farmers labor in the fields from dawn until dusk
She labored over the report for three days straight
The old truck labored up the steep mountain road
He labored to explain the complex theory to students

definitions: work hard physically or mentally especially for long periods of time
move or proceed with difficulty and great effort
examples: Workers laboured through the night to finish the project
She laboured in the garden all weekend planting flowers
The ship laboured through the stormy seas all night
He laboured to understand the foreign language text completely

definitions: fasten or tighten something by threading a cord through holes or hooks
secretly add alcohol or drugs to food or drink
examples: She laced her boots tightly before the long hike
Can you help me lace this corset properly please?
Someone laced the punch with vodka at the party
They laced his coffee with sleeping pills last night

definitions: be without or deficient in something that is needed or desired
examples: The proposal lacks detail in several important areas completely
She lacks the experience needed for this senior position

definitions: apply a hard glossy coating to wood or metal for protection and shine
examples: They lacquered the wooden furniture to protect it beautifully
She lacquered her nails with bright red polish yesterday

definitions: develop a vertical run or tear in stockings or tights
examples: Her stockings laddered when she caught them on the chair
These tights ladder easily so handle them with care

definitions: load someone or something heavily with a large quantity of things
examples: They ladened the truck with supplies for the journey
The trees were ladened with ripe fruit ready for harvest

definitions: serve soup or sauce with a large long-handled spoon with a deep bowl
examples: She ladled soup into bowls for all the guests
He carefully ladled gravy over the roasted turkey slices

definitions: fail to keep pace with others or fall behind in movement or development
examples: Sales are lagging behind projections for this quarter significantly
Don't lag behind the group during the museum tour

definitions: escape or flee hastily especially from the law or pursuit
examples: The suspects lammed it before police arrived on scene
He lammed out of town when creditors started calling

definitions: give birth to a lamb as a sheep does in breeding
examples: The ewe lambed twins during the cold spring night
Most of our sheep lamb in early April each year

definitions: cause a person or animal to become unable to walk normally
examples: The accident lamed the horse permanently affecting its gait
The injury lamed him for several months requiring therapy

definitions: express passionate grief or sorrow about something through words or cries
mourn deeply for a loss or express regret about an unfortunate situation
examples: She lamented the loss of traditional values in society
The poet lamented his lost love in verses
They lamented over the destruction of historic buildings downtown
He still laments the missed opportunity years later today

definitions: cover something with a protective layer of plastic or other material permanently
examples: We need to laminate these documents to preserve them
She laminated her teaching materials for repeated classroom use

definitions: publicly criticize or ridicule someone or something with harsh satire
examples: The comedian lampooned politicians in his latest television special
The satirical magazine lampoons celebrities every week without mercy

definitions: pierce or cut open something with a sharp surgical instrument or pointed tool
examples: The doctor lanced the boil to drain the infection
They lanced the abscess to relieve pressure and pain
